    #Analysis II
    2001

    Define uniform continuity for functions defined on a (bounded or unbounded) interval in R\mathbb{R}R.

    Is it true that a real function defined and uniformly continuous on [0,1][0,1][0,1] is necessarily bounded?

    Is it true that a real function defined and with a bounded derivative on [1,∞)[1, \infty)[1,∞) is necessarily uniformly continuous there?

    Which of the following functions are uniformly continuous on [1,∞)[1, \infty)[1,∞) :

    (i) x2x^{2}x2;

    (ii) sin⁡(x2)\sin \left(x^{2}\right)sin(x2);

    (iii) sin⁡xx\frac{\sin x}{x}xsinx​ ?

    Justify your answers.

    Let A={x,y,z}A=\{x, y, z\}A={x,y,z}, let ddd be the discrete metric on AAA, and let d′d^{\prime}d′ be the metric given by: d′d^{\prime}d′ is symmetric and

    d′(x,y)=2,d′(x,z)=2,d′(y,z)=1d′(x,x)=d′(y,y)=d′(z,z)=0\begin{gathered} d^{\prime}(x, y)=2, d^{\prime}(x, z)=2, d^{\prime}(y, z)=1 \\ d^{\prime}(x, x)=d^{\prime}(y, y)=d^{\prime}(z, z)=0 \end{gathered}d′(x,y)=2,d′(x,z)=2,d′(y,z)=1d′(x,x)=d′(y,y)=d′(z,z)=0​
